[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Karygiannopoulos.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: I would support Councilor Marks' resolution in doing that.

[Caraviello]: We don't have to do them all in one year.

[Caraviello]: Every year, you do a certain percentage of them, and eventually they'll be all done.

[Caraviello]: If Councilor Marks would make that resolution, I would be more than happy to support that.

[Caraviello]: And the long run, it'll be a cost saving, not a cost.

[Caraviello]: Spend a little, save a lot.

[Caraviello]: Again, thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: You know, uh, as we said, you know, the weather's starting to get nice out there.

[Caraviello]: People are walking the dogs.

[Caraviello]: Uh, they're asking, uh, about the dog park that's been proposed before.

[Caraviello]: Where's the funding that we had for it and where it's going to be?

[Caraviello]: There seems to be some confusion and rumor floating around of where the dark pocket is going to be.

[Caraviello]: So I'd like to have the mayor give his proposal on that.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Caraviello.

[Caraviello]: Thank you again, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: I'd like to see the mayor appoint some type of committee.

[Caraviello]: I mean, we have a bicycle commission now.

[Caraviello]: I don't know why we can't have half a dozen residents of the community sit down and maybe propose some spots for these dog parks.

[Caraviello]: So if you could add that onto the amendment.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

[Caraviello]: Frank, I don't have the history that these other people have with TV3, but the bottom line is you have an audience in the city that's looking for TV3.

[Caraviello]: Sure, yeah.

[Caraviello]: And I'm sure all of us here get calls every day, we see people in the street, and they ask us, where is TV3?

[Caraviello]: What's happening with it?

[Caraviello]: And they're not getting

[Caraviello]: There's no communication whether through via the newspaper or.

[Caraviello]: We've talked in the past.

[Caraviello]: I'm saying that the people of this community, they call us, they ask us what's happening.

[Caraviello]: You have an audience in this community that is looking for your programming.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: And they see us in the streets.

[Caraviello]: They see us in the supermarket.

[Caraviello]: They ask us, what's happening there?

[Caraviello]: They don't know.

[Caraviello]: And it's hard for us to give them an answer.

[Caraviello]: Maybe you guys should communicate via the newspaper.

[Caraviello]: Can't you guys go on the government channel?

[Caraviello]: Of all these people are seniors, I don't know how computer literate they are.

[Caraviello]: That's a good part of your audience is the senior crowd, and they look forward to your stuff.

[Caraviello]: That's a point well taken.

[Caraviello]: I mean, update them in the newspaper.

[Caraviello]: I mean, go on the government channel.

[Caraviello]: And maybe, you know, I'm sure you have some, you know, the mayor would give you access to the channel that the council is broadcast on, or the high school users, and let the people know where you are and what's going on.

[Caraviello]: A lot of the seniors don't, aren't computer literate.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: All right, Councilor Caraviello.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: You know, I agree with Mrs. Rose 100% on the budget.

[Caraviello]: Last year, when I joined the council, when I got my first budget here, I was kind of shocked to see how it wasn't an actual budget.

[Caraviello]: And this year, when the budget comes out, I'd like to see an actual budget presented so we know what departments are over and under.

[Caraviello]: I mean, I don't want to see that your department was given $100,000 and they spent $100,000.

[Caraviello]: That's not a budget.

[Caraviello]: I mean, if the school department can do it, I'm sure that this building can do it.

[Caraviello]: I agree with Councilwoman Locarno.

[Caraviello]: It couldn't be fixed.

[Caraviello]: Now, all of a sudden,

[Caraviello]: Well, it's really not that bad.

[Caraviello]: And from day one, I was told it was deplorable and was going to fall down.

[Caraviello]: But now it's kind of OK.

[Caraviello]: Maybe we can make it work.

[Caraviello]: swim team if nobody can see the team.

[Caraviello]: I think that issue needs to be discussed.

[Caraviello]: Everything's gotta work in one.

[Caraviello]: But like I said, I would support her action for the treasurer to give us a report on where we stand on all the ones.

[Caraviello]: On the motion for approval, Councilor Caraviello.

[Caraviello]: So the state, I'm not gonna,

[Caraviello]: Correct.

[Caraviello]: The lawyer says yes.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: I have to have a million and a half dollar policy.

[Caraviello]: Whereas, the strength of our nation is derived from its history of diversity that has enriched our communities with a variety of cultures, faith, traditions, and viewpoints.

[Caraviello]: The following recommendations were made.

[Caraviello]: That one, a traffic plan be submitted to the council and the police chief.

[Caraviello]: Two, construction schedule with start dates, days of weeks, and times be submitted.

[Caraviello]: Three, that Eversource set up an informational meeting at the high school to include

[Caraviello]: the winter street residents in a budding neighborhoods for that a contact name for the project with a telephone number and email be posted to the city's website.

[Caraviello]: Five that plans be provided by ever source on route on the route from question street to the city line that were included seven

[Caraviello]: Eversource develop a regional communication plan.

[Caraviello]: That plan would entail them developing a strategy of contacting TV and radio station, notifying non-Method residents about the project, and to notify them of alternate routes.

[Caraviello]: Before we start the meeting tonight, I know I spoke to a bunch of the press before.

[Caraviello]: City Council rules state if you want to tape, if you want a video, please respect our rules, which are the middle window to the middle window and around the back.

[Caraviello]: Please do not come up here and have your iPhones in people's faces.

[Caraviello]: So if you want to tape, we don't have a problem with anybody taping.

[Caraviello]: Just respect the rules and tape within the certain parameters that we have.

[Caraviello]: It's still not cutting what

[Caraviello]: I will not support any department head or any boss or anybody getting a raise for the working people of the city get a raise.

[Caraviello]: I come from a family who operated a union factory for 40 years.

[Caraviello]: And we always make sure the workers are taken care of first because they're the ones who are the lifeblood of either the company or the city.

[Caraviello]: And that's how it always should be.

[Caraviello]: And it should never be any other way.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, ma'am.

[Caraviello]: They have to pave the whole street.

[Caraviello]: Rules should be the same for everybody.

[Caraviello]: I stopped in the middle of the street, and I said to my wife, I said, I want you to stop and tell me what you see here.

[Caraviello]: She didn't understand.

[Caraviello]: Thank you for everybody with the kind words, former colleagues, present colleagues, and everyone else.

[Caraviello]: But it's been an honor to serve the residential community for the past 12 years.

[Caraviello]: I never once thought of this as a job.

[Caraviello]: It was something that I wanted to do.

[Caraviello]: As I said, when Terry Carter interviewed me for an interview, he says, how did you get involved?

[Caraviello]: And I said, you know, I said, I was like kind of a young kid, 45 years old, and I was kind of at the crossroads, you know, with young kids, and a friend invited me to a Kiwanis meeting.

[Caraviello]: And

[Caraviello]: I got to sit with Paul, and back then there was like 80, 90 people, but they were all pillars of the community.

[Caraviello]: And I'd sit there and I'd listen to their stories, and I said, geez, I'd like to be that person one day.

[Caraviello]: And Paul mentored me along, and here I am today.

[Caraviello]: So I thank the Kiwanis for really getting me involved with the community and showing me what community involvement was all about, because I didn't come from, you know, it's not something that I did, or my dad didn't do it either, so.

[Caraviello]: They taught me community involvement.

[Caraviello]: So I thank my friends at the Quons for that.

[Caraviello]: But I've had a lot of good accomplishments.

[Caraviello]: As you said, I worked hard in the library, like four or five years.

[Caraviello]: And I didn't do it by myself.

[Caraviello]: I thank Mayor Burke for taking something from a Councilor, which no mayor has ever done in the city, and actually brought it to a reality.

[Caraviello]: And I thank Mayor Burke for doing that.

[Caraviello]: And even with the art center, I know Councilor Marks, he was a trailblazer on that.

[Caraviello]: And when that call came in, I knew right away who needed the property.

[Caraviello]: And who do I call?

[Caraviello]: I call another colleague, Councilor Marks.

[Caraviello]: And we got the ball rolling on that.

[Caraviello]: So those are two real things I've did that I'm real proud of.

[Caraviello]: But I've also done some, I'm real proud of some of the veterans things I did.

[Caraviello]: Who in the world would ever know where to find an elevator for free?

[Caraviello]: Really, we got a call and the lady said, I need an elevator for my house, I'm saying.

[Caraviello]: I made a couple of calls in like, in three hours I had an elevator.

[Caraviello]: And I called him back and he says, remember Christmas?

[Caraviello]: He says, we're gonna have an elevator for you.

[Caraviello]: And we got people to put it in for free.

[Caraviello]: And this was from a guy who hadn't been out of this house in four years.

[Caraviello]: We also, we did a home of a veteran, what apparently his daughter.

[Caraviello]: And we got together with the community and volunteers and did almost $300,000 worth of work in this house free.

[Caraviello]: So when I say I started, we did the food program, but it's just things I've done over the years.

[Caraviello]: I don't know how they came to the past, but they did.

[Caraviello]: And I'm happy that I've been able to serve the community.

[Caraviello]: I don't want to belabor the point, but I served under three mayors.

[Caraviello]: Council Marks, and maybe we weren't the best of friends when we got on the council, because he was, you know, I was the new, I was the, even though I was older than him, I was the new guy.

[Caraviello]: I was the new guy on the council.

[Caraviello]: But, you know, over the years, we've been good friends, you know, Councilor Dello Russo, Councilor Falco, Councilor Penta, Councilor Mayorkas, Councilor Musil.

[Caraviello]: I've shared with a lot of good people, including the people that are sitting here today.

[Caraviello]: And, you know, these are memories I'll have forever and ever.

[Caraviello]: And listen,

[Caraviello]: Where I lay in the next few months, who knows, but I'll always be around for anybody who ever needs St.

[Caraviello]: David's.

[Caraviello]: So thank you, and thank you everybody for all the kind words you said tonight.

[Caraviello]: And like I said, I'll miss everybody.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Caraviello]: I think as we all know, doing this job really takes a toll on your family and your family life.

[Caraviello]: Citywide, our total budget was $143,794 last year.

[Caraviello]: We only spent $127 million.

[Caraviello]: That's why we're sitting on all this free cash.

[Caraviello]: While we sat here and begged for stuff last year and the year before,

[Caraviello]: The mayor was squirreling away in her little hiding place.

[Caraviello]: $25 million we're sitting with now.

[Caraviello]: When a lot of these problems that we're fighting for now could have been resolved last year and the year before.

[Caraviello]: We only spent 88% of our budget.

[Caraviello]: The history, go look at your own budget report.

[Caraviello]: You've over-budgeted every single year for everything in the city.

[Caraviello]: That's why we got all this money hanging around.

[Caraviello]: We're begging for stuff.

[Caraviello]: I don't know, I just, you know, this is not fiscal transparency at any point.

[Caraviello]: And I say, and all I say, we sat here and we begged and we begged, and we ended up with nothing last year, and the year before we ended up begging for nothing.

[Caraviello]: But meanwhile, let's hoard the money and screw away $25 million in account that we don't know what we're gonna spend it.

[Caraviello]: We're gonna spend it on this year.

[Caraviello]: I'm just, really, it's,

[Caraviello]: Do you want a response from the chief of staff or no, you don't have that response you put your budget book says it.

[Caraviello]: I'm only going with the numbers you presented to us, through your budget book.

[Caraviello]: Where literally do we do we not over budget the last three years?

[Caraviello]: Do we not over budget?

[Caraviello]: I'm saying there's a pattern here of over-budgeting for the last three years by your own budget book, not Rick Caraviello's numbers coming out of the sky.

[Caraviello]: Who's got a computer here?

[Caraviello]: Anybody got a computer?

[Caraviello]: Pull up the budget.

[Caraviello]: up the budget and see how much money you over budgeted.

[Caraviello]: Not you per se, because you weren't here.

[Caraviello]: I spent the weekend with numbers people.

[Caraviello]: I'm not a numbers guy either.

[Caraviello]: I sat with two budget people who looked at this and one looked at me like I had two heads.

[Caraviello]: I'm sorry.

[Caraviello]: This pattern goes back to 2020, 21 and 22.

[Caraviello]: Go look, go look at your own book that you put out.

[Caraviello]: These aren't made up numbers.

[Caraviello]: All right, so you want to say this year that we had some unknown factors?

[Caraviello]: Well, what happened last year?

[Caraviello]: What happened the year before that?

[Caraviello]: What happened the last three years?

[Caraviello]: She forgot what she wanted to say.

[Caraviello]: She's been waiting so long.

[Caraviello]: I have one last question.

[Caraviello]: So if we knew Clearglove was wrong from day one, why did the mayor come up here and use it in her presentation?

[Caraviello]: that night when she made her presentation, when you knew it was wrong.

[Caraviello]: So all I'm saying is, why did the mayor, knowing that it was wrong, use it in her presentation?

[Caraviello]: And then- We have 10 days to fix it, and we can vote on the budget after they're fixed.

[Caraviello]: So we maybe can make a better estimation over voting on it.

[Caraviello]: I'm looking, if I'm following the numbers, I spent the whole weekend looking at a patent.

[Caraviello]: of over-budgeting, so I only went on the numbers that you gave me.

[Caraviello]: You should have put out a disclaimer to everybody saying, hey, those numbers are wrong, don't go by them.

[Caraviello]: There's many accounts that they can borrow the money from and replenish it when the free cash is certified.

[Caraviello]: Yes.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: I think we all know Henry and Evelyn for their work in Medford, which is tireless, but I've known Henry a long time.

[Caraviello]: For those who don't know him, Henry is well-renowned throughout the state of Massachusetts for his work in that community.

[Caraviello]: And he doesn't get the recognition sometimes that he deserves, but those of us in the hometown, we all know and we recognize his commitment to people with disabilities and things like that.

[Caraviello]: So I just want to salute Henry for his work and glad he's getting some recognition, both him and Evelyn for all the things they do.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Caraviello]: I appreciate Councilor Bears's putting this on there.

[Caraviello]: This isn't just Willis Ave.

[Caraviello]: We're gridlocked in the city.

[Caraviello]: at certain times of the day.

[Caraviello]: I know some of the improvements we made for safety is we've cut down the size of the roads, we've cut down turns.

[Caraviello]: So now people are sitting in traffic for crazy periods of time, they're getting frustrated, and they're going down all these side roads.

[Caraviello]: They say, this is just Willis-Eve.

[Caraviello]: In the morning, the traffic is backing up into Winchester on Winter Street.

[Caraviello]: It's backing up past the train station.

[Caraviello]: This morning,

[Caraviello]: Took me 38 minutes to get into the square from my house in West Medford.

[Caraviello]: High Street is backed up everywhere.

[Caraviello]: So it's a problem, especially between the morning hours and the afternoon hours.

[Caraviello]: We're just gridlocked, no matter where you go in the city.

[Caraviello]: And frustration is, people are going down all these side roads.

[Caraviello]: If you use Waze, it's taking you everywhere.

[Caraviello]: I mean, we've been shut down every road in the city for, you know, certain hours of the day.

[Caraviello]: It's just, it's getting unbearable.

[Caraviello]: They're pretty much going down all those neighborhood streets and flooding those neighborhoods as the traffic keeps getting further up.

[Caraviello]: If you live in the West Method area, you're seeing the lights at Route 16 and Winter Street, three or four cars get through.

[Caraviello]: And the problem over there is because there's two sets of lights on Route 16 that go off in the morning when there's really no one over there, causing the traffic to back up.

[Caraviello]: So now you get three cars go through.

[Caraviello]: traffic's backing up everywhere, and it's backing up on the Boston Ave now on some mornings.

[Caraviello]: What do we have there?

[Caraviello]: We still got the same blinking light.

[Caraviello]: So now the people are going down South Street.

[Caraviello]: and just making our traffic problems larger and larger without thinking before we make decisions.

[Caraviello]: I mean, people, the kids are late going to school in the morning.

[Caraviello]: The bus can't make it there.

[Caraviello]: And they're getting their three, they get three tidies and you got a problem at school.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Falco is absent.

[Caraviello]: Present.

[Caraviello]: 6 in the affirmative, one absent.

[Caraviello]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 38, Section 18 of the Governor's March 15th, 2020 order, imposing strict limitations on the number of people they may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: Specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and parties with a right or requirement to attend this meeting

[Caraviello]: can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medford.org.

[Caraviello]: For this meeting members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Caraviello]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time by a technological means.

[Caraviello]: In the event that we were able to do so despite this efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or community media website

[Caraviello]: an audio, a video recording transcript, a rather comprehensive record of the proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Caraviello]: Motions, orders, and resolutions.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Marks.

[Caraviello]: Just if I could, one recommendation that was made in the most recent report from that ad hoc committee that was set up by the mayor was to provide for a satellite fire station in the Wellington Circle area due to all the recent construction, due to the additional traffic and the nature of getting through that particular area.

[Caraviello]: And, you know, for years,

[Caraviello]: We had a member of this council that brought up that issue back so many years ago, Mr. President, was way ahead of his time, stating that because of the growth in Wellington and the high rises and the need brought that satellite up many years ago.

[Caraviello]: And there were many people in the administration that pooh-poohed it at the time, saying it's ridiculous, it's a ridiculous idea and so forth.

[Caraviello]: And now we're seeing that, we're revisiting that now again, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: And that's a recommendation

[Caraviello]: with the chief just mentioned, this committee that was established that is comprised of many firefighters.

[Caraviello]: And at the time, it was our colleague, Councilor Penta, that brought up that issue over and over again, Mr. President, and it fell on deaf ears.

[Caraviello]: And I just want to thank my colleague for his insight on that issue and the fact that

[Caraviello]: He was always looking out for the best interest of this community.

[Caraviello]: And I believe having a satellite in that particular area is in the best interest of everyone that lives in that area, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: And I look forward to the ultimate recommendations someday of the creation of the satellite.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Chief, would it be possible to build something in the Wellington area, like in conjunction with Malden, something similar to like Revere did?

[Caraviello]: with Malden over by the quarry there?

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, if I could.

[Caraviello]: My comment wasn't directed at any particular administration.

[Caraviello]: It was directed at a need and a concern that was brought up by a member of this city council that we're finally seeing be called and said, you know, saying that there's legitimacy to it and there's a need for it in the community.

[Caraviello]: That's the only reason why I brought it up.

[Caraviello]: Regarding land in Wellington Circle, we know that's like a hen's tooth trying to get land in Wellington Circle.

[Caraviello]: What it is is when we have development coming in, a public-private partnership to say, hey, it's great to build here, but we're going to look for you to put a small satellite that we can house a small fire engine and department in there to make sure we maintain the safety.

[Caraviello]: This is how we have to get creative, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: It's not going out and looking for the city to buy land.

[Caraviello]: It's creating these public-private partnerships to accomplish what our goals are as a community.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: On the motion by Councilor Scarpelli, seconded by Councilor Falco, Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Okay, that's right.

[Caraviello]: 2-1, 3-1-6.

[Caraviello]: Our mutual agreement.

[Caraviello]: Dear Mr. President, city councilors, I respectfully request or recommend that pursuant to Mass General Laws, Chapter 48, Section 59A, the city council, by affirmative vote of this communication, authorize the city of Medford Fire Department to go to aid another city, town,

[Caraviello]: fire district area under federal jurisdiction in this commonwealth or any adjoining state and extinguishing fires therein or rendering any other emergency aid or performing any detail as ordered by the head of the fire department or the joint base Cape Cod fire district.

[Caraviello]: And while in the performance of their duties in extending such aid, the members of our department shall have the same immunities, privileges that they were performing the same within this municipality.

[Caraviello]: This is a resolution, this is a reauthorization of the Metro Fire Mutual Aid Agreement that was executed in November 2001 for a 20-year term, and will expire on October 31st, 2021.

[Caraviello]: Chief of the Department, Frank Gilberti, will be present to answer any of the Councilor's questions.

[Caraviello]: Sincerely, Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn.

[Caraviello]: Chief Gilberti.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Chief.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, I think I brought this up earlier.

[Caraviello]: I think this is a huge tool that we need to be part of.

[Caraviello]: Like I said, two fires in Somerville, the Chief just mentioned right now in Everett, that we can help each other

[Caraviello]: when it comes to something as devastating as fire and safety and wellness for our communities.

[Caraviello]: And it goes both ways.

[Caraviello]: I know that when we've had some serious fires here in Medford, we would often see neighbor communities here supporting our firefighters or at least covering our stations while our firefighters were out on the call.

[Caraviello]: I move approval and like again, like I said to the Chief Gilberti, we appreciate everything our men and women do in our fire department and making sure everybody is safe and not only for our community, but our neighboring community.

[Caraviello]: So thank you.

[Caraviello]: Second the motion.

[Caraviello]: All in the motion by Councilor Scarpelli, seconded by Councilor Falco.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Mux.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: And I want to thank Chief Gilberti,

[Caraviello]: I do have just one comment, Mr. President, that, you know, who really needs the mutual aid is our current firefighters who are going through a very difficult negotiation, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: And that's where the mutual aid is needed right now in our community.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: on the sites.

[Caraviello]: And if you drive down that stretch of Winthrop Street, say from, oh, the gateway of Medford, from the Winchester line into Medford, past Temple Shalom, to the end of Victory Park, if you drive past the entrance of historic Oak Grove Cemetery, which we just invested, what, about a million bucks of community preservation money into, you'll find about 25 to 30 steel plates stacked up, rusted out, that have been sitting there all winter long, Mr. President, that they use to cover the holes that they make on the street.

[Caraviello]: Again, in violation of the requirements and policy that we asked them to keep debris free from the street.

[Caraviello]: And also if you drive a little bit further past Victory Park on the left hand side, Mr. President, you'll see an inordinate amount of kerbstone, granite kerbstones that have just been piled up there for months on end.

[Caraviello]: This isn't what I would expect from a public contractor doing utility work here in our community.

[Caraviello]: So my motion regarding the most preferable locations was the following, to locate them in industrial districts, if not adjacent to a park, playground, school, residential district, or historic district.

[Caraviello]: So the most preferential would be an industrial district.

[Caraviello]: The second one would be a public right of way in areas not adjacent to parks, playgrounds, schools, or residential districts.

[Caraviello]: So if you live in a residential area that abuts an industrial district or public right of way, this would not be a preference.

[Caraviello]: So in your case, Marianne, it would not be located near your parcel or housing.

[Caraviello]: They went into the lowest socioeconomic areas of the city of Medford, where they'll get the least resistance.

[Caraviello]: Okay, public participation.

[Caraviello]: By David McKenna, 94 Rockland Road, FMS.

[Caraviello]: I, David McKibbin, would like the opportunity to discuss public properties in Medford and the procedure of changing said name.

[Caraviello]: I would further like the clarification on what rights the majority of the city have in being able to have healthy dialogue and discussion when it comes to said changes.

[Caraviello]: This issue has been a dividing wall in our city, and citizens are not feeling like they have a say in the matter.

[Caraviello]: Moving to the record, please.

[Caraviello]: Good evening, David McKillop, 94 Rockland Road.

[Caraviello]: I want to say thank you for allowing me to have the opportunity to speak on this situation.

[Caraviello]: And the only reason why I'm here right now is because there's a large majority of people that I've spoken to and that really were working really hard to have their voices heard with an issue reference the changes in names of certain buildings in the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: And to understand why we're here today, in fact, I was just kind of listening to everything and it was encouraging to see how unified we all got behind the 5G situation.

[Caraviello]: And I hope that somewhere along the line, we can get unified in many other areas in the city.

[Caraviello]: And it's unfortunate that we can unify on one situation and then divide in another situation.

[Caraviello]: And that's where we're at right now with this process.

[Caraviello]: The reason why I'm here is to talk a little bit about a recent change and the way it went down in June 6th.

[Caraviello]: There was a decision and a vote that one of the buildings in Metro would be changed with the name.

[Caraviello]: And it was kind of, the way the process went was people felt like they weren't heard.

[Caraviello]: People felt they didn't even have the opportunity to speak.

[Caraviello]: And even in the patch, I know that it was the,

[Caraviello]: the final hour that it was presented on the patch that there was the opportunity for people to speak in a meeting for this change.

[Caraviello]: And then about two or three weeks ago, we had the opportunity again to speak.

[Caraviello]: I spoke, I know I spoke on a Monday night and really tried to kind of tug at the sympathy and the respect of

[Caraviello]: the people that feel disenfranchised, and the reason why they feel disenfranchised, and please indulge me in a little bit of a history lesson, and I'm sure some of you know this, why the heck is a guy with the name McKillop even interested in this?

[Caraviello]: Well, my mom's maiden name is Joanne Camela Labasse, so I'm just as interested in what's going on as anyone else that's interested in this.

[Caraviello]: Columbus, it is something that is of historic significance for not just the name and not just the person,

[Caraviello]: but for the reason behind it.

[Caraviello]: Columbus is a word now that symbolizes something that's very important to the Italian-American community.

[Caraviello]: Columbus, back in the 1800s for Italian-Americans, was a person that did do a lot of discovery.

[Caraviello]: But in the late 1800s, 1890s, I don't know if a lot of you know this, but Italian-Americans were treated very poorly.

[Caraviello]: In fact, I would go as far as to say like dirt.

[Caraviello]: They were treated so poorly that there were certain Italian-Americans that were accused of a murder they did not commit and were acquitted.

[Caraviello]: And people didn't like that.

[Caraviello]: So they actually pulled these people, dragged these people out of a jail and they lynched them.

[Caraviello]: They lynched them.

[Caraviello]: They lynched Italian-Americans.

[Caraviello]: And this got so bad.

[Caraviello]: This got so bad in the United States that two countries were separating because of it.

[Caraviello]: the United States and Italy.

[Caraviello]: Dignitaries from Italy were removed from the United States.

[Caraviello]: Dignitaries from the United States were removed from Italy in the 1800s.

[Caraviello]: Imagine this situation and how it catapulted the Italian American community into a totally different level.

[Caraviello]: In 1891, the president of the United States recognized what was going on, recognized that this just cannot continue.

[Caraviello]: So he did something unprecedented in its time.

[Caraviello]: He went and he offered condolences and money to the families of the lynched Italian-Americans to help them offset the situation.

[Caraviello]: He also took it one step further.

[Caraviello]: And with the help of the Italian consulate, he created a day

[Caraviello]: of remembrance and gathering and family, and that was called Columbus Day.

[Caraviello]: It was only supposed to be one event, one event, and then it goes away.

[Caraviello]: That became so important to the Italian American community because what it did was it took them away from a racist situation.

[Caraviello]: There it is, that's the word.

[Caraviello]: This was a tool, a facility that the president of the United States put together

[Caraviello]: with Italy to remove racism or help move the Italian-American community closer to inclusiveness.

[Caraviello]: It became so important that it became Columbus Day, that it was so important to the Italian-American community that Italy itself created a statue, not unlike the Statue of Liberty, and sent it over to the United States in response to what the president did.

[Caraviello]: So Columbus is not Christopher Columbus, the person, not just that anymore.

[Caraviello]: And by the way, looking at a person through the lenses of today, shame on us.

[Caraviello]: Shame on us.

[Caraviello]: The history that people are talking about, the jury is still out on that.

[Caraviello]: We're not quite sure.

[Caraviello]: So let's really just understand where we are today.

[Caraviello]: Christopher Columbus and that statue meant a heck of a lot more to Italian American people

[Caraviello]: than what is perceived as of today.

[Caraviello]: I was really happy and kudos to Councilor Bears for bringing out the transgender day.

[Caraviello]: Kind of the same thing.

[Caraviello]: It's interesting.

[Caraviello]: We could bring out a transgender day and yet we can start to remove this icon of a name from buildings.

[Caraviello]: Now I'm hearing that it's being considered to be removed from parks.

[Caraviello]: Now I'm hearing that we're moving on to other names.

[Caraviello]: I mean, where does this end?

[Caraviello]: Where does this go and where does this end?

[Caraviello]: At what point do we start taking a stand and saying, this is our community, let's breathe through the nose.

[Caraviello]: And if we're going to make changes, first of all, I want you all to understand, we know the decision was made.

[Caraviello]: We also know it has nothing to do with the city council in the respect of making that decision.

[Caraviello]: That's not what we're here for today.

[Caraviello]: We're here to say our voices were not heard.

[Caraviello]: When we had the opportunity to be heard, we were given two minute intervals and we were asked not to repeat.

[Caraviello]: Not unlike the part that you're frustrated with, with 5G, right?

[Caraviello]: You are very frustrated with that.

[Caraviello]: Imagine the people on that Zoom meeting because, and no disrespect to anyone, we can't come here to talk to the city council.

[Caraviello]: So we have to talk to them on Zoom.

[Caraviello]: I'm sorry, on school committee, my apologies.

[Caraviello]: So we had to talk to them on Zoom and we were given two minute intervals and asked not to repeat ourselves.

[Caraviello]: Can't even get a point across in two minutes, I'm sorry.

[Caraviello]: And I tend to be a bit long-winded, so I like to speak.

[Caraviello]: So that's the reason why I'm here today, to let the city council know there is a group of disenfranchised

[Caraviello]: people in the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: It doesn't make any sense to me that we can allow that when we're talking about so many other things that address those issues.

[Caraviello]: So we need to work together.

[Caraviello]: We need to come together.

[Caraviello]: We need to start getting back to the gravity zero center of the city.

[Caraviello]: and stop extreming everything that we do.

[Caraviello]: This is a dividing rod for this city.

[Caraviello]: It's appalling that it's happened.

[Caraviello]: And when we have elected officials saying, I don't care how many people say they don't want to change, it will be changed.

[Caraviello]: That is a sign that this city is coming apart.

[Caraviello]: When we have the people signing a petition

[Caraviello]: And over 630 people signed that petition and gave it to the school committee and said, hey, we don't want this to happen.

[Caraviello]: And 300, just over 300 people said, hey, we do want this to happen.

[Caraviello]: Common mathematics say two thirds of the people do not want it to happen.

[Caraviello]: When does this stop?

[Caraviello]: Where do we go from here?

[Caraviello]: And if we can't communicate here, then where?

[Caraviello]: If we can't communicate now, then when?

[Caraviello]: And if we can't communicate to them, and we can't communicate to you, then who?

[Caraviello]: And this is where we're at today.

[Caraviello]: So pardon me if I'm a little upset about this.

[Caraviello]: This was something that was, in my eyes, swept completely under the rug.

[Caraviello]: It's a done deal.

[Caraviello]: And now they're putting together a committee to name this building.

[Caraviello]: I'm sorry, but if you read the bylaws of that committee rules, if you don't agree with them, give up.

[Caraviello]: What kind of a committee is that?

[Caraviello]: Where are we at?

[Caraviello]: We need your help.

[Caraviello]: We need your guidance.

[Caraviello]: We need some understanding.

[Caraviello]: Where is this city going and what is happening?

[Caraviello]: And this is not gonna stop with just the school.

[Caraviello]: It's gonna be a park.

[Caraviello]: It's gonna be a street.

[Caraviello]: It's gonna be anything else.

[Caraviello]: And let's take it one step further.

[Caraviello]: Anybody in the United States

[Caraviello]: who had done wrong things in their life, paid the price, went to jail, got accosted, and then turned their life around and did good things.

[Caraviello]: What will history look at them like?

[Caraviello]: Let's take it in a step further.

[Caraviello]: A celebrity business person anywhere in the United States makes a donation to another city.

[Caraviello]: Where do they go when they're looking for that?

[Caraviello]: Mr. McKillop,

[Caraviello]: You're coming upon your 10 minute mark.

[Caraviello]: Okay, thank you.

[Caraviello]: So I leave you with just this.

[Caraviello]: What makes the human spirit work is this.

[Caraviello]: What drives us is this.

[Caraviello]: What makes us so great is that we are imperfect and we learn from the people before us.

[Caraviello]: We don't erase them.

[Caraviello]: I thank you for your time this evening.

[Caraviello]: Mary Ann Braxton.

[Caraviello]: Mary Ann.

[Caraviello]: We're not, we're not discussing that this evening, Marianne.

[Caraviello]: Yes, but may I make a meeting earlier on that?

[Caraviello]: Back point of information is there's not even a discussion of public participation, the individuals come up and they say that we're speaking at this particular issue at the moment.

[Caraviello]: Come back and speak on that.

[Caraviello]: I would say though, that this isn't the appropriate forum to debate the, you know, ongoing legacy of Christopher Columbus.

[Caraviello]: That's not what we have.

[Caraviello]: Let me just the record, please.

[Caraviello]: Anthony D'Antonio.

[Caraviello]: This is a very contentious issue with me.

[Caraviello]: Columbus

[Caraviello]: Park, Columbus School, the South Medford neighborhood where it exists.

[Caraviello]: It's very special to many, many, many Italian-Americans, Irish-Americans, Russians, and so on and so forth, because that was the neighborhood.

[Caraviello]: The Columbus was not just a school.

[Caraviello]: It was a family.

[Caraviello]: My grandfather came from the Southern mines in Italy and busted his hump to realize the American dream.

[Caraviello]: Never asked for anything.

[Caraviello]: My other grandfather, same thing.

[Caraviello]: Donated to that school.

[Caraviello]: Donated to the St.

[Caraviello]: Clement Church.

[Caraviello]: They worked hard.

[Caraviello]: They never put their hand out like everybody's doing today.

[Caraviello]: Give me more, give me more.

[Caraviello]: All right?

[Caraviello]: So it's not just the school.

[Caraviello]: And shame for this stranger who comes to the city of Medford and decides he doesn't like Italians, so he's gonna change his damn name.

[Caraviello]: I'm sorry, but that's not good.

[Caraviello]: We're not going down that road.

[Caraviello]: All right, we're not going to go down that road.

[Caraviello]: What you're doing is you're taking history away from the people in South Metro.

[Caraviello]: We're not going down that road.

[Caraviello]: No, they're taking history away from the people in South Metro.

[Caraviello]: You don't do that, all right?

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: They ought to do something different with their lives.

[Caraviello]: Name and address of the record, please.

[Caraviello]: Just a quick follow-up.

[Caraviello]: Dave McKellar brings up a good point as it related how Italians were treated.

[Caraviello]: Because if you go into some of the social media here in Medford, they do take a swipe at Italians.

[Caraviello]: And I resent that very much, whether I'm Italian American or whether you're Irish American, no matter what it might be.

[Caraviello]: And if anybody really needs to know, of all the immigrants that came into this country, it was the early Italian Catholics who came into this country as immigrants, and they struggled to make their way

[Caraviello]: And they were hostilely treated, hostilely treated throughout the entire United States.

[Caraviello]: In 1785, they wanted to build a church in Manhattan, New York.

[Caraviello]: This goes back a little bit in history here.

[Caraviello]: And St.

[Caraviello]: Peter's Church, which was the heart of where the Catholics made their proposal to build their church.

[Caraviello]: But the pushback was from the people at that time, they feared the papacy and the sinister foreign influences that was forced upon them to relocate outside the city limits.

[Caraviello]: And on December 24th, in 1806, two decades after the church was built, on Christmas Eve, there was an enormous, how can you say, meltdown at the church because people just didn't like what was going on.

[Caraviello]: Resulting from that, on Christmas Eve, there was a protest in which dozens of people were injured and a policeman was killed.

[Caraviello]: That's the sad part about the early part of immigration as it relates to the Italians here in this country.

[Caraviello]: And then as Councilor McKillop, excuse me, Mr. McKillop alluded to, on March 14th, 1891, the biggest lynching then and now in the United States of America was against the 10, 11 Italians, falsely accused and acquitted in a court of law of killing a police chief.

[Caraviello]: And there was a mob riot after that situation that took place.

[Caraviello]: And because of that mob riot that took place, the then

[Caraviello]: and he was becoming the president of the United States, Teddy Roosevelt, who everyone thinks he was a great guy, he might be in some people's, he indicated it was rather a good idea that those people were lynched.

[Caraviello]: And then a gentleman, his name was John Parker, who helped organize the lynching said the following, he said of Italians, that they are just a little worse than the Negro, being if anything filthier in habits, lawlessness and treacherousness.

[Caraviello]: Why isn't that?

[Caraviello]: And that today, that today spell, unfortunately, divisiveness that's taking place.

[Caraviello]: The Medford social media, for those people who wouldn't even have the tolerance to allow a different conversation to their revisionary history, has alluded to exactly what Mr. McKillop is talking about.

[Caraviello]: This is not taking place in the city with this particular Columbus school issue.

[Caraviello]: You have a former principal, Marie Rizzo, who wrote a very fine letter to the mayor and every school committee person on her thoughts about that name change, and she did not get one response as of last Sunday.

[Caraviello]: That's total disrespect to a woman who spent over 42 years as an educator here in the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: And if we look at the history,

[Caraviello]: of the Columbus School.

[Caraviello]: It goes back to September 6, 1929, in the midst of Mercury, where the story goes, it was because of the neighborhood people who got together and raised money for the school, that that's the reason why the then school committee changed the name from the Mystic School to the Columbus School, because they were of Italian American descent.

[Caraviello]: The Medford School Committee and the mayor ought to be ashamed of themselves for not only entertaining this, but now they want to have an intermediary next month before school starts, change the name one month ahead of time, and then go into making a final change.

[Caraviello]: You want to talk about having kids all screwed up and parents all screwed up.

[Caraviello]: There it is right there, a school committee that can't even listen to the people.

[Caraviello]: It's a shame.

[Caraviello]: What you guys did tonight set the tempo of how a discussion should take place.

[Caraviello]: The school committee has lost that ability and they've let one person.

[Caraviello]: another town to come here from two years ago to take over and move an issue.

[Caraviello]: I didn't mention his name.

[Caraviello]: We're not going to bring up anybody's character.

[Caraviello]: I said I didn't mention his name.

[Caraviello]: I don't care.

[Caraviello]: He came into the community and he changed.

[Caraviello]: I'll set you up.

[Caraviello]: You can't set me up.

[Caraviello]: I didn't mention his name, Rick.

[Caraviello]: I'm asking you to be polite here.

[Caraviello]: Just get with him.

[Caraviello]: Don't be afraid of the truth, Rick.

[Caraviello]: This is the truth, okay?

[Caraviello]: I'm asking you to be polite here.

[Caraviello]: We're not doing anything.

[Caraviello]: I'm telling you about the school committee.

[Caraviello]: The school committee- Mr. President, with all due respect, the reason that we created public participation and adjusted it this way was so the councilors and citizens wouldn't get into debates.

[Caraviello]: I think that the whole idea is that we're gonna sit back, let him say what he's gonna say, and then let's move on because I don't think anybody behind this rail is really interested in having a discussion about whether or not the school committee made the right decision or not, quite frankly.

[Caraviello]: I think we all have our own opinion on it, but it's not within the purview of this board.

[Caraviello]: I feel as though it's nothing more than a dog whistle, Mr. President, at this point.

[Caraviello]: Okay, thank you.

[Caraviello]: So I just concluding to say, as Councilor Knight has alluded to, you know, they come here to say whatever our opinion is.

[Caraviello]: And I think the 5G issue basically said the whole story.

[Caraviello]: You have the opportunity to hear it.

[Caraviello]: You knew it took place on March 31st.

[Caraviello]: You're not going to hopefully have the same thing on Thursday night.

[Caraviello]: And all I'm saying, and I think as my two predecessors who came here to speak, was what's taking place on the school committee does not represent the best interests of the city of Metro.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Those ships have sailed, so to speak, the proverbial ships.

[Caraviello]: The reason I'm coming up is because I want to know, to follow up with Mr. McGillip said, what can we do as a city council to help prevent this from occurring over and over and over?

[Caraviello]: Is there anything this council can do to enact an ordinance or some type of rule to prevent this from becoming a problem?

[Caraviello]: I'm not talking about the school committee, with all due respect to the president.

[Caraviello]: But going forward on other buildings, there is no actual procedure in writing.

[Caraviello]: Understood.

[Caraviello]: Maybe if the administration wants to adopt an actual procedure, that is up to them.

[Caraviello]: But currently, there is nothing in writing that gives us a procedure on where to go.

[Caraviello]: Exactly, councilor.

[Caraviello]: And that's why I'm saying, can this council take a step in that direction to help present

[Caraviello]: You could see that you could feel the anger in the air, just in this room with only so many people in here.

[Caraviello]: Can you imagine what's going on in the rest of the city?

[Caraviello]: Of course you have.

[Caraviello]: And again, I don't want to go on and on about this.

[Caraviello]: I'm trying to move forward, okay?

[Caraviello]: I'd like to see this council, if possible, and I'm asking if you could get your heads together and come up with some type of rule or something just to show that, you know, hey, you can't just come in here and just all of a sudden just change some rules because you said so, because you felt like it.

[Caraviello]: We need some input from citizens in this city, okay?

[Caraviello]: Before large decisions are made.

[Caraviello]: Again, I don't expect you to check with every individual person in the city.

[Caraviello]: That's not what I'm saying.

[Caraviello]: But there should be better communication when large decisions are made with members of the city.

[Caraviello]: And that goes, I'm not speaking for the school committee.

[Caraviello]: I'm speaking for the city council and the school committee.

[Caraviello]: I would just appreciate it if,

[Caraviello]: If, you know, especially during the pandemic where some of us feel marginalized because I don't want to say any, any groups, you know, but there's some people who weren't really good with zoom and, uh, they weren't able to get on and voice their opinion.

[Caraviello]: These people, they feel marginalized because this all happened and they feel like it happened behind their backs.

[Caraviello]: Uh, they may say it happened in June and they had all this time, but you know, I don't want to talk about the committee anymore.

[Caraviello]: What I'm trying to say is please see if you could put your heads together and come up with something.

[Caraviello]: to help not so much prevent this, but just that the community can have more participation and say in such large decisions.

[Caraviello]: I would appreciate that.

[Caraviello]: I respect you for listening to me tonight.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Name and address for the record, please.

[Caraviello]: Sure, what is that address?

[Caraviello]: If you can give me a proper address, it would be appreciated.

[Caraviello]: We miss you.

[Caraviello]: There's good and bad in every race, creed, religion, including cops and politicians.

[Caraviello]: I want to commend Councilor, excuse me, David McKillop for having the courage to come forth and bring this issue before us.

[Caraviello]: The only guy that had more courage, and he had more courage than everyone in this city, 57,000 people, was Christopher Columbus himself, who wanted to prove the world was around, and no one in Europe believed him, except for maybe some of the Knights Templars.

[Caraviello]: And he would have proved it,

[Caraviello]: if it wasn't brought by the two continents.

[Caraviello]: The English were here first, after the Indians were here originally.

[Caraviello]: I understand.

[Caraviello]: And then the discrimination started from day one.

[Caraviello]: As the Irish knew, they did not apply for a job.

[Caraviello]: The Italians, they went through hell.

[Caraviello]: They're still being discriminated against.

[Caraviello]: Today, I have proof.

[Caraviello]: personal.

[Caraviello]: It's just, the way it was, the name was taken away, it was not fair to the people, they had no, no forum in person.

[Caraviello]: And I can go on and on and on.

[Caraviello]: I want to mention Sacramento and Manhattan and New Orleans, Louisiana, they were pulled out of the jail and hung.

[Caraviello]: I think I'm just gonna cut it short.

[Caraviello]: See, I'm disappointed.

[Caraviello]: However, I'm gonna ask the city council, with all your legislative powers that you still claim very often, can you put this in the November ballot to save, keep, and reclaim Christopher Columbus' school name?

[Caraviello]: Is that possible and doable?

[Caraviello]: If somebody wants to, if a council wants to do that, that's.

[Caraviello]: This doesn't fall, that doesn't fall within our purview to change names.

[Caraviello]: You want to, is that possible?

[Caraviello]: If someone wants to make a motion, they can do that.

[Caraviello]: It is possible.

[Caraviello]: I don't think anybody wants to even get into this situation.

[Caraviello]: We've already said this from the start.

[Caraviello]: It's a done deal.

[Caraviello]: The school committee made the decision.

[Caraviello]: The decision has been made, the scout says there's no power to overturn it.

[Caraviello]: If you want to go out and get some signatures and put it on the ballot, that's your option.

[Caraviello]: I'm still working on my own occupied real estate tax exemption, chapter 59, section 5C, for 21 years.

[Caraviello]: This is not fair.

[Caraviello]: You insulted, not you, some peoples have insulted a lot of people in this city.

[Caraviello]: And it's not gonna stop.

[Caraviello]: It's horrendous.

[Caraviello]: Matter of fact, this political correctness is turned by Christmas.

[Caraviello]: Upside down.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Andrew.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: We have one more person here, Councilor Marks.

[Caraviello]: We have Miriam Brock, would you like to speak?

[Caraviello]: On this?

[Caraviello]: No.

[Caraviello]: I'd like to speak on this.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Marks.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: And I want to thank the speakers for coming up tonight.

[Caraviello]: You know, this has always been an open forum for anyone that would like to come up and vent their concerns, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: And that should never, ever, ever change.

[Caraviello]: Whether I agree or disagree, everyone has the right to come up here or on Zoom and express their thoughts and opinions.

[Caraviello]: And we should never, never take that right away.

[Caraviello]: You know, my opinion, I've been in government 26 years now.

[Caraviello]: I'm not, you know,

[Caraviello]: afraid to say that, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: I'm proud of my years in service.

[Caraviello]: I think the one major flaw with this process is the fact when the resolution was offered, it was offered to do something certain by a certain date.

[Caraviello]: It wasn't inviting people to give input and say, what are your thoughts about this?

[Caraviello]: How do you feel about this?

[Caraviello]: Let's take the name out of it.

[Caraviello]: It doesn't matter who the name is.

[Caraviello]: The names are interchangeable.

[Caraviello]: The process was flawed from the start because it didn't ask for public input and give people the ability to get up there and say, these are my issues.

[Caraviello]: And once that happens and you set that into motion, right away, you're going to disenfranchise a certain number of people on the other side, whichever side it may be.

[Caraviello]: Sometimes you may be on the prevailing side.

[Caraviello]: Sometimes you may be on the losing side.

[Caraviello]: That doesn't matter.

[Caraviello]: So right inherently what happened from the start is this process was flawed because right away it said, we're going to do this and by a certain date.

[Caraviello]: And that's a problem, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: If the resolution read, we're gonna discuss this and look for input, we're gonna discuss other options, other alternatives, it would have been a whole different scenario.

[Caraviello]: And I've heard this from members of the community, even people that are pro change in the name and people that are against change in the name.

[Caraviello]: I've had more people come up to me that are against change in the name saying it has nothing to do with Columbus.

[Caraviello]: Honestly, nothing to do with Christopher Columbus.

[Caraviello]: It has all to do with the process.

[Caraviello]: And when there's a sense of frustration out there, as you're hearing, and it starts to build up, this is what you're gonna have.

[Caraviello]: You're gonna have a divided community.

[Caraviello]: And it's really unfortunate the way it rolled out.

[Caraviello]: I don't think anyone else behind this wheel can speak to the fact that I was the only member behind this wheel to actually vote on a school name.

[Caraviello]: The only member.

[Caraviello]: And guess what?

[Caraviello]: Guess what?

[Caraviello]: I voted against the name that was offered by the school committee.

[Caraviello]: And I won't bring up the name because the school's named after that person now, and so be it.

[Caraviello]: I was the only member to vote against it.

[Caraviello]: And my reasoning was at the time, Mr. President, that the school committee changed their policy because you had to be deceased in this city under the school committee farmer policy in order to have a building named after it.

[Caraviello]: And they took a vote to change the policy because they wanted to name it after someone that was very much alive

[Caraviello]: So they changed the process in order to name it after who they wanted to.

[Caraviello]: And I was a new member of the school committee.

[Caraviello]: It was a difficult vote.

[Caraviello]: It was against a very prominent person in this community.

[Caraviello]: But I stood tall, Mr. President, because that's what I believed in.

[Caraviello]: And I think that's what's happening now, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: The process is inherently flawed.

[Caraviello]: And we're never gonna be able to come to the middle with a flawed process.

[Caraviello]: And I would respectfully ask

[Caraviello]: the school committee to reconsider.

[Caraviello]: Take a look, revisit this.

[Caraviello]: There's no rush to judgment, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: That school's been named that way for 100 years.

[Caraviello]: There's no rush to judgment, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: It's more important to me that this community unite, especially during these difficult times, than to try to pass an agenda.

[Caraviello]: That to me is far more important that we unite as a community, like we heard about 5G.

[Caraviello]: So I would respectfully ask that the school committee, when they're in their deliberations, I know they set timeframes and so forth, but they respectfully look at what is being done to this community, ripping this community apart.

[Caraviello]: Some of these wounds you're not gonna be able to heal, but guess what?

[Caraviello]: It's not done right now.

[Caraviello]: So we have time to say, let's take a step back, let's take a look at it.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Morell.

[Caraviello]: Marianne's been waiting a while, and we have a couple of others after Marianne.

[Caraviello]: So she's been waiting a while, so we'll let Marianne speak.

[Caraviello]: Marianne Bruxton.

[Caraviello]: Marianne?

[Caraviello]: Mr. Gabb, it's again, it's an environmental justice area, which was named by the- I just want to make sure because we did have a close to a two hour meeting prior to this meeting.

[Caraviello]: And I just want to set the record straight.

[Caraviello]: The report we received from J.M.

[Caraviello]: Golson regarding the draft housing production plan.

[Caraviello]: If you look at it on page 82, it talks as Mary Ann just mentioned,

[Caraviello]: about the chapter 40B projects that are currently in the pipeline in the community.

[Caraviello]: And this is the report, this is not me stating it.

[Caraviello]: It says if all four of these projects come to fruition, Method will have an additional 1,087 units eligible to be counted on the subsidized housing inventory, bringing the city's portion of the SHI units to 11.7%.

[Caraviello]: So I just want to set the record straight.

[Caraviello]: that according to this report, that's not me, and the consultant that was hired, if these four projects in the pipeline, the 40B projects come to fruition, we will be over the SHI rate that's required by the state.

[Caraviello]: That's why it's 1,000, it's 1,000 something, 1,087.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Just if I could, just to clarify.

[Caraviello]: The city of Medford is not dictating where these 40B projects are gonna go.

[Caraviello]: What happens is because we don't meet the 10% threshold which is required by state statute, they're able to come in into 40B, which allows them to circumvent state law.

[Caraviello]: And that's what's happening right now.

[Caraviello]: So they can pop up and go anywhere they want in the community.

[Caraviello]: We're not picking particular sections for them to go in.

[Caraviello]: This is what is allowed under state statute 40B.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Marianne, are you finished?

[Caraviello]: Marianne?

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Marianne.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, a couple of things.

[Caraviello]: Number one, the MBTA determines the level of service and the level of service for our bus community is based upon ridership.

[Caraviello]: So if there's ridership, then the bus services should increase in a perfect world.

[Caraviello]: The MBTA gives us a very large assessment and that assessment based upon the services that we deliver to this community, number one.

[Caraviello]: Number two, when it comes down to where the development comes from, like Councilor Mack said,

[Caraviello]: property owner petitions the city for a comprehensive permit under Chapter 40 B. They petition the city for a comprehensive permit under Chapter 40 B, it bypasses local zoning.

[Caraviello]: You know, so if the concern is how many people are gonna be riding the bus, ridership drives the level of service at the MBTA.

[Caraviello]: And I think that the city clerk, having been the former chief of staff, they can probably confirm that.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: All right, Marianne, are you?

[Caraviello]: Yes, thank you.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Marianne.

[Caraviello]: 21307 offered by Councilor Knight, Councilor Scarpelli, and Councilor Falco.

[Caraviello]: Be it resolved that Medford City Council send its deep and sincere condolences to the family of Alan McDougal on his recent passing.

[Caraviello]: Vice President Knight.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, thank you very much for allowing me a moment to remember my friend Al McDougal.

[Caraviello]: I first met Al as a freshman in high school trying out for the football team, and Al was our freshman football coach.

[Caraviello]: And I went on to play lacrosse that spring, and Al was our freshman lacrosse coach as well.

[Caraviello]: And over those years, since my freshman year in high school, I've been able to develop a great relationship with Al.

[Caraviello]: He was a Metro Mustang through and through.

[Caraviello]: He was captain of the last Metro High School football team that won the Greater Boston League Championship.

[Caraviello]: And just recently, he passed away while on the line of duty working for Verizon.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Vice President.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Councilman.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Council President.

[Caraviello]: Um, it's a sad day when we have to talk about the passing of a true legend.

[Caraviello]: Uh, Alan McDougal meant a lot to a lot of people.

[Caraviello]: And you could see that by the outpouring of, of condolences to toward his friends and his ceremony last week and, and just celebrating his, uh, his life and just knowing him.

[Caraviello]: Um, yeah, Alan was a true, true definition of blue and white flowing through the veins.

[Caraviello]: I know Mr. Kelly, uh, when he brought that to Medford,

[Caraviello]: There was one person that stood up and followed that, and then pushed that along to everybody else to make sure everybody knew what that meant.

[Caraviello]: It's just not a statement of words, but it's a way of life.

[Caraviello]: And it's sad because I think that if people loved Medford the way Alan loved Medford, a lot of the issues we have today wouldn't be issues.

[Caraviello]: And when you have that much passion, that much love, and that much respect for the blue and white, for the city of Medford, for what it stood and what it stands for,

[Caraviello]: Alan was that true leader to do that, whether it be on the football field or whether it's coaching with him when we were coaching, you know, he was coaching football, I was coaching soccer.

[Caraviello]: Alan was this big opposing figure that would scare most people.

[Caraviello]: And I still remember Alan in high school, you know, typical, you know, walked around as a typical jock

[Caraviello]: angry, you know, you get so nervous as a young kid.

[Caraviello]: But I'll never forget Alan's demeanor and how he would just walk up to you make you feel welcome.

[Caraviello]: And it took away so many of those stereotypical thoughts of what high school was all about, you know, or the big captain of the football team and how he was supposed to respond to younger kids.

[Caraviello]: But Alan didn't do anything that we were told it was going to happen to our kids.

[Caraviello]: He was a kid that brought people in and gave them a lesson and how to love Medford.

[Caraviello]: and be a Mustang.

[Caraviello]: And I've said this way too often too lately, is who's gonna pick up that baton.

[Caraviello]: When people like Alan McDougall leave us, who is gonna be the next person to pick up that baton?

[Caraviello]: And I hope as we move forward, I know that his friends, you know, looking at scholarships and so people can actually benefit

[Caraviello]: from Alan's death, but also spread his word and who he was, so we can really keep his name alive.

[Caraviello]: And I'll tell you, there was one sad day when I got that phone call to say Alan Tugel just died.

[Caraviello]: So rest in peace, my friend, and I'll make sure that in my life, in my circles, that his name and his legacy will never be forgotten.

[Caraviello]: So thank you for bringing this forward constantly.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Falco.

[Caraviello]: You know, I couldn't say enough with my colleagues already said, I appreciate Council Vice President Knight putting us on.

[Caraviello]: You know, the old saying, don't judge a book by its cover.

[Caraviello]: It's exactly what Councilor Scarpelli mentioned.

[Caraviello]: When you first looked at him, you say, wow, this guy would, you know, pretty intimidating.

[Caraviello]: And the way he came across, he was big in stature and so forth, but you couldn't meet a nicer, kinder, gentler person that really would go over and above to make someone else feel welcomed.

[Caraviello]: And he just had that personality about him.

[Caraviello]: And he will sorely be missed.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, his love was to his teammates, his love was to sports in this community and student athletes.

[Caraviello]: And it really showed through the work he did for many years, volunteering and so forth.

[Caraviello]: So my heart goes out to his family and friends.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Personally, he was a gentleman.

[Caraviello]: Believe it or not, I probably saw the guy four days a week.

[Caraviello]: talk to him for at least four days a week.

[Caraviello]: He's a good person, a good family, and he's going to be sorely missed in our community.

[Caraviello]: Before we leave, I just want to give a couple of notes, just share a couple of notes.

[Caraviello]: Everybody, we've got an email today, starting on Wednesday, April 14th.

[Caraviello]: It's evening work to start the overnight work for safety improvements for South and Main Street, starting this next Wednesday through its completion.

[Caraviello]: They're talking about painting of the lanes, signage and some barriers.

[Caraviello]: So it's exactly what they have put through for traffic calming initiatives that will be implemented until the study is done and then move forward with the full time traffic signal at that location.

[Caraviello]: So I know that people have been talking about that.

[Caraviello]: They still haven't seen anything, but it's good to hear that Wednesday night you'll see some action and hopefully that leaves for

[Caraviello]: a safe corridor for the time being until it's permanently completed.

[Caraviello]: The second thing I wanted to share is I know that a couple of months ago we were here with a food truck permit and there was some questions and issues and concerns and there was some anger and some things were said.

[Caraviello]: I just want to share something with everybody that

[Caraviello]: When that happened, before the meeting was over, I got a text from a few restaurants in the city.

[Caraviello]: And I know Vivian Sue, the president of the Andrews Middle School, she works diligently for the kids to make sure that they have funding for any sort of activities for the kids, even through this pandemic year.

[Caraviello]: A fundraiser, thanks to Marie Carroll and Carroll's Restaurant, they're providing a fundraiser, which is a true fundraiser.

[Caraviello]: He's doing for food in-house, anybody that comes with the flyer from the Andrews, 30% of the proceeds will go back to the school and the takeout 40% of the proceeds will go back to the school.

[Caraviello]: So I think this is the true indication of what we're trying to go that evening with that our restaurants, our brick and mortar buildings were hurting.

[Caraviello]: And we knew that if there could be an organization that would help, you know, we, I think there were three restaurants that were mentioned, and Carroll's, Razzo's, I think Salvatore's, but these restaurants stood up and Marty's Carroll's stepped up again.

[Caraviello]: And I know that, I don't know, I'm watching what I'm eating, so I can get a salad, but I'll definitely pie that.

[Caraviello]: I just watch.

[Caraviello]: But I just wanted to share those two,

[Caraviello]: to issues with the community.

[Caraviello]: 15th regular meeting of the Medford City Council, April 13th, 2021.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Bears.

[Caraviello]: Present.

[Caraviello]: Present. Please rise and salute the flag.

[Caraviello]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, chapter 30A, section 18, and the Governor's March 15th, 2020 order, imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted by a remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right of requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medford.org.

[Caraviello]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Caraviello]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Caraviello]: In the event that we're able to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or community media website, an audio or video recording transcript, a rather comprehensive recording of the proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[Caraviello]: Okay.

[Caraviello]: Before we start, our Board of Health Director is not able to attend this evening, so she did send me a brief report.

[Caraviello]: So since we've had, since 4-1, we've had 160 cases.

[Caraviello]: The majority of those cases are 111 are under 40 years of old.

[Caraviello]: As she states, this is not a time to let our guard down.

[Caraviello]: Mask wearing and testing are still extremely important.

[Caraviello]: All 16 year olds plus are eligible as of Monday and should preregister now on the state website.

[Caraviello]: We were scheduled to do 50 homebound with the Johnson & Johnson vaccine this week, but they were put on hold due to the feds holding it for more investigation.

[Caraviello]: We will be in touch with those people to reschedule as soon as possible.

[Caraviello]: We look forward to seeing Marianne.

[Caraviello]: Oh, excuse me.

[Caraviello]: Our largest 46 cases are between the ages of 20 and 29.

[Caraviello]: So it seems to be that the bulk of the cases are coming in from the younger people who are getting out and being a little homebound.

[Caraviello]: So we'll have an update again next week.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Thank you very much.

[Caraviello]: Tonight we are here to congratulate Max Stephens for being part of a team that won the

[Caraviello]: gold medal for hockey in the Deaf Olympics that were held in Italy this past December.

[Caraviello]: Max, for those of you who don't know, was only 17 years old and he participated on a team that had teammates 25 to 35 years old, which is somewhere 10 years older than Max.

[Caraviello]: Max played an integral part in this team.

[Caraviello]: I think his dad told me he got a couple of goals and he had a pretty good season.

[Caraviello]: Max has overcome his disability, for those of you who don't know, and this has come over the years.

[Caraviello]: I've known him since he was a little boy, but he's overcome this with a lot of hard work and dedication, and we're seeing the fruits of what's happened for the fine things that he's done.

[Caraviello]: When someone looks at the word disability, it immediately conjures up the idea of what someone could not do, or something physically wrong,

[Caraviello]: with that injury that prevents them from doing something as the majority of society can do.

[Caraviello]: Well, Max has proved everyone wrong, and being here tonight with his family and the gold medal is a tribute to his hard work and dedication.

[Caraviello]: Max, people will always remember your name, but your success today tells a story of your indomitable courage and your inspiration for others to follow.

[Caraviello]: Be the same forever and add many more feathers of success to your crown.

[Caraviello]: Congratulations to you and your family,

[Caraviello]: as you have done yourself, your family, and the city of Medford proud.

[Caraviello]: But, you know, there is, like he said, you know, there's not a place where you go and you don't find these little bottles all over.

[Caraviello]: I come out of my own house every day.

[Caraviello]: But believe it or not, they're on.

[Caraviello]: At the liquor store, they're one of the largest sellers at their, no matter what store you go into.

[Caraviello]: I've talked to several different stores and some guys said they sell almost $1,000 a day, if not more.

[Caraviello]: I don't know who's buying them.

[Caraviello]: Obviously, people are buying them, and they're buying them quite frequently.

[Caraviello]: So hopefully with this five cent deposit, similar to how people are picking up cans and bottles all over the street, hopefully people will start picking up these little small bottles too.

[Caraviello]: So I wholeheartedly support this.

[Caraviello]: Motion to revert back to regular business.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: We talked about the budget.

[Caraviello]: I'll ask... We'll talk about the budget again.

[Caraviello]: I'll ask you to convey this to the mayor, and it's something that's been a sore spot since the day I've been on this council, is that we have an actual budget.

[Caraviello]: And we've had it for a couple of years, and then we didn't have it.

[Caraviello]: So again, I don't wanna just see what's proposed.

[Caraviello]: Again, like we had a couple of budgets ago, we saw what was spent in the past.
