[Caraviello]: To the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, City of Medford, proposed ordinance, Historic District, dear Mr. President and members of the City Council, I respectfully request and recommend that your Honorable body approve the following amendments to the City of Medford revised ordinance entitled, Historic District Commission Article 3, Section 48-51, as described below.

[Caraviello]: These amendments clarify the ordinance to delineate the previous approved

[Caraviello]: districts, and at the request of the Medford Historic District Commission, create a new single parcel historic district at 16 Foster Court.

[Caraviello]: By way of background, section 48, that's 51A, under the authority of Master General Law, section chapter 40, section 3, there is hereby established a Hillside Avenue

[Caraviello]: On the motion by Councilor Naito, waive the reading, seconded by?

[Caraviello]: Second.

[Caraviello]: Seconded by Councilor Miz.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: I think Mr. President, Mr. Bailey mentioned it's a procedure.

[Caraviello]: And I think the whole thing here is because of the procedure.

[Caraviello]: The historical group was tasked five years ago to go out and identify historical pieces of property.

[Caraviello]: And currently, the procedure is, you buy the property for us, and then we'll tell you if it's historical.

[Caraviello]: That's- I mean, this is not the procedure that you should have.

[Caraviello]: Point of information.

[Caraviello]: Point of information, Councilor Bears.

[Caraviello]: Vice President Caraviello, please continue.

[Caraviello]: Again, it's a procedure.

[Caraviello]: That's the problem.

[Caraviello]: It's not whether the district is good or bad, it's a procedure.

[Caraviello]: This property was purchased 18 months ago.

[Caraviello]: They didn't get around to it until month 16.

[Caraviello]: So now the burden is on us, because everyone sat on it for a year and a half, all this time, and now the burden is on this group to do a last minute decision.

[Caraviello]: Where were you the last 16 months negotiating with this guy?

[Caraviello]: Did nothing happen during the 16 months that you had to wait until August 28th, the end of the August meeting, to decide that you wanted to make this a historical news?

[Caraviello]: Why couldn't you have decided that in February of 19, when this was put in?

[Caraviello]: So I don't think it's fair to this group to put us in this position that wasn't created by us.

[Caraviello]: Well, if there's so many properties, why aren't you identifying them?

[Caraviello]: Where's the list?

[Caraviello]: I haven't seen a list.

[Caraviello]: I don't think anybody in this group has seen a list of properties that have been identified.

[Caraviello]: Again, until you guys come up with a procedure, this is going to happen every time somebody buys a property.

[Caraviello]: Again, 16 months has gone by, 17 months has gone by, and now we're here at the 18th hour with the panic being put on us.

[Caraviello]: Okay, thank you.

[Caraviello]: This is a matter that's come to my attention.

[Caraviello]: If anyone is driven by Vernon Street, you'll see that they're in the process of currently putting in a new sidewalks, some new curbing and the paving the street.

[Caraviello]: So, for those of you aren't familiar, Vernon Street is kind of cut in half.

[Caraviello]: I'd say it goes on the Mystic Street end versus the All Street end.

[Caraviello]: So one half of the street has granite curbing.

[Caraviello]: The other half of the street, from what I'm told, was supposed to have granite curbing, and either the contractor wasn't able to get it, so they've decided to put in a concrete curb.

[Caraviello]: And anyone knows how good a concrete curb is.

[Caraviello]: One plow hits it, it's pretty much done.

[Caraviello]: But that's not so much the issue of the concrete curb.

[Caraviello]: The issue is you have historic homes there, and this is not the type of curbing that belongs in front of historic homes.

[Caraviello]: Everyone else in the city has granite curbs.

[Caraviello]: These residents deserve the same curbing as everybody else.

[Caraviello]: I know he said they couldn't get it.

[Caraviello]: I don't know why they can't get it.

[Caraviello]: Everyone else seems to have curbing.

[Caraviello]: But it would be my motion to not pave that section of Vernon Street until a decision is made whether to put granite curbs in, because these people deserve it and their house, everyone else has it, versus the concrete curbing that is in the neighborhood now.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Caraviello]: I don't know if Councilor Tang just asked my question, but I don't see the Asian population represented here.

[Caraviello]: And they're the largest growing segment of our community right now.

[Caraviello]: I was with some people in Somerville and they just put on

[Caraviello]: an Asian liaison in their community.

[Caraviello]: So I hope that we can do that.

[Caraviello]: I will make sure that I'm getting them.

[Caraviello]: And I will make sure that you're getting the information that you need.

[Caraviello]: I also had a grandchild that went to school today either because of her fear.

[Caraviello]: Instead of being here tonight advocating for funding, hiring teachers, school repairs, or asking for supplies, I'm here tonight to add my voice to the groundswell of anger and outrage that so many are feeling regarding the recent violence at Bedford High School.

[Caraviello]: So now I am demanding adequate resources, security, to help keep our students safe.

[Caraviello]: First off, let's get one thing straight.

[Caraviello]: Stabbing yesterday was not an isolated incident.

[Caraviello]: Fully has been going on for a long time at the high school.

[Caraviello]: Didn't just start yesterday.

[Caraviello]: A gun clip found in a middle school auditorium during a school vacation was an isolated incident.

[Caraviello]: No one was hurt.

[Caraviello]: Gun clips by themselves don't hurt people, but knives and physical violence do.

[Caraviello]: Everyone who engages in the community could see this coming a mile away.

[Caraviello]: Fully has been escalated, unchecked since the start of the school year.

[Caraviello]: But rather than address the situation on early,

[Caraviello]: school officials, superintendent, school committee, and the mayor consistently downplayed each and every incident, hoping it would go away.

[Caraviello]: It was unconscionable that no comment, acknowledgement, or plan of action was implemented immediately.

[Caraviello]: What are we thinking?

[Caraviello]: We all know when people aren't thinking.

[Caraviello]: Yesterday's school committee meeting was another pointless charade of the council needs to work together and not yell at us.

[Caraviello]: Let me tell you something.

[Caraviello]: I've been working here for 11 years.

[Caraviello]: I've gotten yelled at many times.

[Caraviello]: If you can't take getting yelled at, then don't run for office.

[Caraviello]: I've been willing to work together with any elected body since the first day I was elected.

[Caraviello]: People are justifiably angry.

[Caraviello]: It's become quite clear that when the teachers had a vote of no confidence, it was directed to the school committee and the mayor's chair.

[Caraviello]: I'm tired of seeing my city, Medford, in the media recently, with a glaring negative spotlight now focused on our community.

[Caraviello]: It's evident that we're not ready for this prime time.

[Caraviello]: I was astonished to hear our superintendent say on television last night, we don't encourage bringing weapons to school, encourage.

[Caraviello]: Statement I find boggles to say at least.

[Caraviello]: How about zero tolerance statement for any weapons and violence of any kind, and we'll act swiftly and with determination to eradicate this unacceptable behavior and prosecute anyone who violates this policy to the fullest extent of the law.

[Caraviello]: That's what our superintendent should have said.

[Caraviello]: Here's another mind twister.

[Caraviello]: Biffin High has no expulsion policy or program in place.

[Caraviello]: What measures does it send?

[Caraviello]: Do you want, and don't worry, you won't get kicked out of school.

[Caraviello]: After all, everyone is entitled to an education.

[Caraviello]: No, not if they're a danger to this community.

[Caraviello]: And all this begs the question, where is the mayor in all this?

[Caraviello]: I hope this just goes away, not showing leadership.

[Caraviello]: That's not a surprise to me here either.

[Caraviello]: So where do we go from here?

[Caraviello]: First, keep the police present in our high school indefinitely.

[Caraviello]: 392 students called out today.

[Caraviello]: Students, teachers, and parents demand a safe learning environment.

[Caraviello]: This is a first step.

[Caraviello]: Bring in Councilors to talk to our affected students and ensure them that the situation now finally is being addressed.

[Caraviello]: Schedule multiple listening sessions for parents and community members to express their feelings and vent.

[Caraviello]: Give them your absolute promise that this ends now.

[Caraviello]: Go through the school incident logs and put problem students on the notice immediately.

[Caraviello]: Again, it's an insult to say this was an outside incident.

[Caraviello]: The kids at the school have seen a growing power vacuum of non-discipline with the recent bully and failing body to act up themselves.

[Caraviello]: It's copycat pure violence and simple.

[Caraviello]: Lastly, hold yourself accountable and admit that

[Caraviello]: You minimize the problem instead of deflecting the blame.

[Caraviello]: That's the only way to move forward from this.

[Caraviello]: The principal and superintendents should put a clear professional plan in place to start 2023 right.

[Caraviello]: We owe it to our children and their future.

[Caraviello]: We can fix mistakes that were made, but if someone loses their life due to needless violence, that's not a mistake that anyone can fix.

[Caraviello]: I'm proud to be a graduate of Bedford High School and I have many fond memories of my time there.

[Caraviello]: What kind of memories are these children gonna have

[Caraviello]: for the eight years at Medford High.

[Caraviello]: We can change that, but we've got to act now.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Madam Superintendent, I have a question.

[Caraviello]: What I'm a little concerned about what I'm seeing now is these are looking like staged events.

[Caraviello]: These are kids standing there waiting for this to happen.

[Caraviello]: And that upsets me most.

[Caraviello]: I mean, I saw the video, this one, another one says,

[Caraviello]: and kids are standing there with the cameras, like this is a TV show production waiting to happen.

[Caraviello]: Everyone's got a camera.

[Caraviello]: Let them go to the TV station and put their skills at our TV station at the high school.

[Caraviello]: It is, I mean, the challenges that we're facing.

[Caraviello]: Not saying they're waiting for fights to happen.

[Caraviello]: That really upsets me when I see that.

[Caraviello]: I'm not saying that's your fault, but that upsets me when there's a whole bunch of kids waiting, because they all knew that this was going to happen.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Caraviello]: Madam President, through you to the superintendent.

[Caraviello]: Do we know how many reports like this are throughout our school?

[Caraviello]: I mean, yesterday when I was there with Councilor Scarpelli, I heard the young lady telling Councilor Scarpelli about her incidents

[Caraviello]: with going to the police and believe it or not, I probably heard the same story from a half a dozen other people that were standing outside waiting for the drone saying they had all filed police reports.

[Caraviello]: I say I met half a dozen people outside what's what's on Councilor Scarpelli yesterday.

[Caraviello]: And they were all saying the same thing that you know, they all they all have reports.

[Caraviello]: They will restraining orders and I don't know why they're not being enforced.

[Caraviello]: I mean, can we get a number?

[Caraviello]: So I have I did another request we won't get.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Caraviello]: I take the speech for itself and motion for approval.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Caraviello]: Pretty simple resolution.

[Caraviello]: Anyone who drives down South Quarter Road right now, especially in the winter where it gets dark at five o'clock, very dangerous road, 17 sets of lights out on that stretch between, especially there's, I think,

[Caraviello]: five or six lights are right at the beginning of South Florida road, where all the homes are.

[Caraviello]: Like I said, it's very dangerous on that road, especially in the dark, animals are running out of the woods.

[Caraviello]: For anyone who travels that Route 16 bypass road, which goes by the DPW yard, City of Medford turning into overnight truck parking spot.

[Caraviello]: Good evening.

[Caraviello]: 13th regular meeting of the Medford City Council.

[Caraviello]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Bears.

[Caraviello]: Present.

[Caraviello]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, Chapter 30, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order, imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather or place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted by a remote

[Caraviello]: participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Caraviello]: Specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and their parties with a right or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medford.org.

[Caraviello]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Caraviello]: No in-person attendance of members will be publicly permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public

[Caraviello]: access to proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Caraviello]: In the event we were able to do so, despite their severance, we will post on the city of Medford or community media website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Caraviello]: Okay, break it in.

[Caraviello]: Mary Ann, is Mary Ann on the call here?

[Caraviello]: see, do I see Mary Ann?

[Caraviello]: I don't see Mary Ann.

[Caraviello]: Oh, there she is.

[Caraviello]: Good evening, Mary Ann.

[Caraviello]: Mary Ann, if you can give us a brief update of what's happening with the vaccinations.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mary.

[Caraviello]: Any further questions for Mary Ann?

[Caraviello]: No, okay, Marian, I wanna thank you again for being here this week.

[Caraviello]: I'm sorry.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Mr. President, this is something that's been discussed over many, many, many times in the city.

[Caraviello]: I think four years ago, we purchased a whole bunch of new cars, and all those cars now have over 100,000 miles on it.

[Caraviello]: I remember at the time we talked about setting up a plan where we be purchasing cars every year.

[Caraviello]: So we're not in a point like this where we have to go out and buy seven or eight cars.

[Caraviello]: And again, that plan never materialized.

[Caraviello]: So at this point, I'm asking us, I'm asking the administration to set up a plan to buy police cars every year.

[Caraviello]: No, you don't have to buy 10 a year, but if you move two or three every year, we're not in the dream world now.

[Caraviello]: So we don't have all these cars sitting there with hundreds of thousands of miles, even though we have an in-house mechanic.

[Caraviello]: We're just spending money repairing cars, because these are cars that run 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

[Caraviello]: So I asked the administration to look into this purchase, especially where cars are in high demand right now.

[Caraviello]: It may take you longer than normal to even maybe even find a car, if there are any police cars available.

[Caraviello]: So I asked the mayor to look into this, and for the administration to come up with a plan

[Caraviello]: We're constantly purchasing cars every year, one or two at a time, so we don't have to do this backlog of waiting to do this.

[Caraviello]: So, so that it's, I don't have a problem with us coming up with a complete capital plan.

[Caraviello]: That'll take some time.

[Caraviello]: Of course, yeah.

[Caraviello]: But, you know, but I'd like to come up with a plan just for this.

[Caraviello]: Like I said, I don't have a problem with this being part of a capital plan.

[Caraviello]: That's not a problem.

[Caraviello]: Councilor Bears, I think that's all they're making for the police departments right at this particular moment.

[Caraviello]: Very few companies make four-door sedans anymore.

[Caraviello]: So the four-door SUV, small SUV, is the way of most cars in the country.

[Caraviello]: I said, I don't think most cars, Ford seems to be the choice of police car, and they no longer make a four-door sedan.

[Caraviello]: So that seems to be the trend in police cars throughout the whole country.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: This is something that we, we had discussed last year when the administration did a review of the clerk's office and they said it was only gonna take a couple of weeks and we're almost at the end of January.

[Caraviello]: And if the, if the administration would be so kind to share the results of those findings where the clerk's office does come under the city council to find, so you can let us know what the findings of the report were.

[Caraviello]: And also if you could give us the cost the legal costs associated with that review of the clerk's office.

[Caraviello]: Communications from the mayor, 22049, to President Morell and all members of city council.

[Caraviello]: On behalf of the Community Preservation Committee, I respectfully request and recommend Your Honor to approve the following recommendations of the Community Preservation Committee.

[Caraviello]: Requesting appropriation of $75,000 from

[Caraviello]: CPA Historic Reserve to the Medford Fire Department for design and engineering to the windows of three historic fire substations.

[Caraviello]: Requesting the appropriation of $350,000, $236,383 from the CPA Housing Reserve and $118,617 from the CPA General Reserve to the Medford Housing Authority for pre-development designs

[Caraviello]: for the walking court redevelopment.

[Caraviello]: Requesting the appropriation of $148,000 from the CPA Open Space Reserve to the Office of Planning, Development and Sustainability for the Riverbend Park Remediation Phase II project.

[Caraviello]: And requesting the appropriation of $54,000 from the CPA Historical Reserve to the Office of Planning, Development, Sustainability, Civic Auditorium and Convention Center Commission for accessibility improvements at the Chevalier

[Caraviello]: theater.

[Caraviello]: This project will be tracked in the community preservation fund by category housing historic space historic open space in general reserve.

[Caraviello]: Thank you for your cooperation.

[Caraviello]: Respectfully submitted.

[Caraviello]: This is something I brought up, I think, two weeks ago in regards to a couple of the boxes in the city that were strewn with trash all around them.

[Caraviello]: I got a call from a gentleman from Planet Aid explaining to me what happened.

[Caraviello]: and to get it cleaned up, but he had asked me why we don't have an ordinance in the city of Medford in regards to regulating these boxes.

[Caraviello]: And I didn't know.

[Caraviello]: And he, in turn, sent me a couple of ordinances from different cities.

[Caraviello]: And they were pretty good.

[Caraviello]: But what he explained to me is what's happening is there's people that come out with boxes.

[Caraviello]: And they just put them on people's property.

[Caraviello]: And people don't know.

[Caraviello]: A lot of people, they're absentee landlords or things.

[Caraviello]: They don't know where they came from.

[Caraviello]: And there's no identification of where the boxes are.

[Caraviello]: In fact, I didn't realize that Planet Aid

[Caraviello]: It's got six boxes in the city.

[Caraviello]: I don't know where they all are, but there's boxes out there.

[Caraviello]: There's boxes for books.

[Caraviello]: There's boxes for a lot of things.

[Caraviello]: But some of these companies that operate these are for profit.

[Caraviello]: They're not all non-profit organizations.

[Caraviello]: And what also happens is now they're becoming garbage dumps.

[Caraviello]: Because people have a television, they don't want to spend the $25 to get the ticket for waste manager to take it.

[Caraviello]: Or there's just toys that they can't fit in the barrel and the rubbish man won't take them.

[Caraviello]: And now these guys that own these bins, spending thousands and thousands of dollars.

[Caraviello]: to what started out as a good idea for donations, now they're becoming trash receptacles for people who have nowhere to go with their rubbish.

[Caraviello]: So I ask that the solicitor adopt an ordinance, and I have a couple that I'll forward to her that was given, and to establish a permit and fee process for the city of Medford.

[Caraviello]: I will send her a couple of the ordinances that he sent me from a couple of different cities.

[Caraviello]: Other cities require them to put a point of contact on them and get permission from the property owner to put this box on so you know that it's in the right spot.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Caraviello]: Over the weekend, myself and Councilor Falco took a workshop in regards to some of these things, but in talking to some people in regards to this, I'm led to believe that the city is able to go out and bring in an advocate.

[Caraviello]: similar to a project manager that we have in particular.

[Caraviello]: But this person here goes out and advocates for the city for the 40B projects.

[Caraviello]: And, you know, the historical commission meets once a month.

[Caraviello]: What are you going to, what are they going to do when there's 40 people that are going before them, you know, with permits?

[Caraviello]: They only meet once a month, and they don't have any funding to hire people to sit there and sort through all these.

[Caraviello]: People could be waiting two months for a building permit.

[Caraviello]: Can I ask what prompted this after all these years?

[Caraviello]: I'd say kind of sounds like more like a bit of a power play to me than anything else.

[Caraviello]: I'll yield the floor to my other councillors.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: Thank you.

[Caraviello]: I've gone down there myself on many occasions.

[Caraviello]: That's a two-lane road.

[Caraviello]: You can barely fit one car down there, because they park on both sides of the street.

[Caraviello]: And the worst part is, it isn't that they're just parking there.

[Caraviello]: When they leave,

[Caraviello]: they leave all their trash behind.

[Caraviello]: And it's not fair to those residents in that area.

[Caraviello]: They have to go through this every single summer.

[Caraviello]: during this time.

[Caraviello]: Winchester had a similar problem.

[Caraviello]: They addressed it, and they made no weekend parking all the way around where the Winchester Boat Club is, because they were getting inundated.

[Caraviello]: But I said, drive down there on a Saturday and Sunday, you'll count the 150 cars parked all the way down Pine Ridge, all the way down to the other end, and they're going on to the other streets, all in that area.

[Caraviello]: These people need some kind of help on the weekends.

[Caraviello]: You know, up on Fulton Street, up by the top of Fulton Street by Rice Pond and up by the Fells, the MDC, DCR puts up horses so people don't park on all those streets.

[Caraviello]: I can't understand why these people can't get the same relief on their streets also.

[Caraviello]: And again, if there was ever a fire down there, there's no way you're feeding a fire truck down that street.

[Caraviello]: Because as they say, because they're so clogged.

[Caraviello]: And let's say, plus the neighborhood is just being overrun.
